definition[0]: not honest, and so deceiving or cheating people
example[1]: People on welfare are wrongly seen as lazy or dishonest.
definition[1]: behaving in a way that is intended to deceive people, for example by lying, cheating, or stealing
example[2]: Are you accusing me of being dishonest?
example[3]: The money was acquired through dishonest means.
example[4]: People are no longer surprised to find that politicians are dishonest.
definition[2]: using your power in a dishonest way for your own advantage – used about people in official positions
example[6]: Law and order has broken down, and most government officials are corrupt.
definition[3]: good at secretly thinking of clever plans to trick people in order to get what you want
example[7]: You have a very devious mind!
example[8]: They use all kinds of devious methods to find out your personal details.
definition[4]: underhand methods involve secretly deceiving people in order to get what you want
example[9]: In a series of underhand moves, Browne managed to gain control of the company.
definition[5]: doing or saying things secretly, in a way that seems wrong because it is slightly dishonest or unfair
example[10]: It was pretty sneaky when the bank charged me interest on my account without telling me.
definition[6]: deliberately behaving in a way that hides what you are really thinking or doing, in a way that is slightly dishonest
example[11]: Lucy decided not to tell him where she was going. She was often a bit sly like that.
definition[7]: using dishonest and unfair methods to get what you want, without caring if you harm other people
example[13]: Some unscrupulous companies try to persuade people to borrow huge sums of money.
definition[8]: deliberately deceiving people in an illegal way in order to gain money or power
example[14]: You will be prosecuted if you make a fraudulent claim on your insurance policy.
definition[9]: if someone or something seems suspicious, they make you think that something dishonest or illegal is happening
example[15]: The police are treating the boy’s death as suspicious.
definition[10]: if something seems dubious, you think it may not be completely true, right, or honest
example[16]: He has a rather dubious reputation.
example[17]: It all sounds highly dubious to me.
example[18]: the country’s dubious record on human rights
definition[11]: shady business deals or people seem to be dishonest or connected with secret and illegal activities
example[19]: Several senior members of the party had been involved in shady deals.
definition[12]: someone who looks shifty looks as if they are doing or planning something dishonest
example[21]: The man on the market stall looked a bit shifty when he gave me my change.
definition[13]: probably dishonest and not to be trusted – used especially to say that you do not want to be involved with someone or something
example[22]: There’s something a bit dodgy about him.
